TITLE: Generating Printing-Corrected Polyhole Primitives in OpenSCAD
DESCRIPTION: This snippet introduces modules and functions to produce 3D printable holes and tubes with corrected dimensions for manufacturing accuracy. It is intended for designers using OpenSCAD who need holes to print 'true to size' regardless of printer idiosyncrasies. Dependencies include OpenSCAD and the NopSCADlib core utility modules. Key parameters include radii, diameters, side counts, chamfering options, twist for poly_cylinder, and length measurements. Outputs include circles, cylinders, rings, and tubes sized for printing, with options for CNC routing, twist compensation, and correct internal diameters. Limitations: Twist increases modeling complexity, and settings may impact print time.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/readme.md#_snippet_283

LANGUAGE: OpenSCAD
CODE:
```
// Polyhole and printing-corrected geometry tools
corrected_diameter(d, n=undef)   // Diameter with polygon flats on the circle
corrected_radius(r, n=undef)     // Radius for polygon flats
sides(r, n=undef)                // Optimum polygon sides for printing
Modules:
drill(r, h=100, center=true), poly_circle(r, sides=undef), poly_cylinder(r, h, center=false, sides=undef, chamfer=false, twist=0), poly_drill(r, h=100, center=true), poly_ring(or, ir, sides=undef), poly_tube(or, ir, h, center=false), slot(r, l, h=100, center=false)
// Usage: Adjust parameters for part fit accuracy and printing requirements. See hydraraptor.blogspot.com/2011/02/polyholes.html for rationale.
```

TITLE: Belt calculation and visualization functions
DESCRIPTION: Contains functions to model timing belts, calculate their length, and generate pulley paths. Includes support for open and closed loops, twists, and different belt types, suitable for parametric belt design.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/readme.md#_snippet_16

LANGUAGE: OpenSCAD
CODE:
```
function _belt_points_info(type, points, open, twist, auto_twist, start_twist) { ... }
function belt_length(type, points, open = false) { ... }
function belt_pitch_to_back(type) { ... }
function belt_pulley_pr(type, pulley, twisted=false) { ... }

module belt(type, points, belt_colour = grey(20), tooth_colour = grey(50), open = false, twist = undef, auto_twist = false, start_twist = false) { ... }
```

TITLE: Gear Profile and Calculation Functions in OpenSCAD
DESCRIPTION: This collection of functions and modules provides tools for designing involute gears, racks, and worms, including profile calculation, gear dimensions, and center distance computations. It supports advanced gear modeling, including helical and bevel gears, with parameters like module, teeth count, pressure angle, and clearance. Dependencies include external gear formula references and utility modules.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/readme.md#_snippet_267

LANGUAGE: scad
CODE:
```
`center_distance(m, z1, z2, pa = 20)`
Calculates the center distance between gears based on module, teeth count, and pressure angle.

`involute(r, u)`
Calculates the involute of a circle at radius r and angle u in radians.

`involute_gear_od(m, z, pa = 20)`
Computes the outside diameter of an involute gear given parameters.

`involute_rack_tooth_profile(m, pa = 20, clearance = undef)`
Generates the profile of a rack tooth based on gear parameters.

`involute_worm_profile(m, pa = 20, clearance = undef)`
Produces a profile suitable for worm gear threading.

`profile_shift(z, pa)`
Calculates the profile shift for small gears to avoid undercutting.

Modules:
`involute_gear_profile(m, z, pa = 20, clearance = undef, steps = 20)`
Computes gear profiles for given gear parameters.
`involute_rack_profile(m, z, w, pa = 20, clearance = undef)`
Calculates rack profile given module, teeth, and pressure angle.

```

TITLE: Sweeping 2D Profiles Along 3D Paths
DESCRIPTION: This section defines utilities for creating swept volumes by sweeping a 2D profile along a 3D path. The code includes functions to create various paths. It supports open or closed paths. Additional twist around the path can be specified. It uses `rounded_path()` to generate paths with rounded corners. `spiral_paths()` generates spiraling paths along a given path.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/readme.md#_snippet_281

SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/readme.md#_snippet_181

LANGUAGE: OpenSCAD
CODE:
```

```

TITLE: Drag Chain - Module: drag_chain
DESCRIPTION: The `drag_chain(name, size, travel, wall = 1.6, bwall = 1.5, twall = 1.5, clearance = 0.1, supports = true, screw = M2_cap_screw, screw_lists = [[1,0,0,1],[1,0,0,1]])` module is the constructor for creating a drag chain. The module takes numerous parameters including `name`, `size`, `travel`, wall thicknesses, clearance, support settings, and screw types.  The `screw_lists` parameter specifies which screw positions are used.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/readme.md#_snippet_129

LANGUAGE: OpenSCAD
CODE:
```
drag_chain(name, size, travel, wall = 1.6, bwall = 1.5, twall = 1.5, clearance = 0.1, supports = true, screw = M2_cap_screw, screw_lists = [[1,0,0,1],[1,0,0,1]])
```

TITLE: Modeling Bezier Cable Strips with nopscadlib (OpenSCAD)
DESCRIPTION: Creates a flexible cable strip model using a Bezier curve via the `bezier_cable_strip` module. Parameters define ways (cable width identifier, e.g., 20), depth (bend radius area), length (total material length), below (vertical offset), extra (additional length), and optional position (bend amount, default 0). Corresponds to a 170mm x 26mm x 0.8mm polypropylene strip.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/readme.md#_snippet_27

LANGUAGE: openscad
CODE:
```
bezier_cable_strip(20, 50, 150, 100, 10)
```

TITLE: Constructing Rounded Rectangular Shapes with OpenSCAD Modules
DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides modules for generating rectangles, cubes, and squares with rounded corners in OpenSCAD, useful for ergonomic and printable designs. Required dependencies are the NopSCADlib and OpenSCAD core modules. Parameters accept vectors for sizes, radii for corner rounding, and boolean options for XY and Z centering. Outputs are 2D and 3D shapes (`cube`-like and `square`-like) with user-controlled rounding and placement. Limitations: Corner radius must be appropriate for supplied shape dimensions; edge-case handling follows OpenSCAD conventions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/readme.md#_snippet_284

LANGUAGE: OpenSCAD
CODE:
```
// Rounded rectangle and cube modules
rounded_cube_xy(size, r=0, xy_center=false, z_center=false)
rounded_cube_xz(size, r=0, xy_center=false, z_center=false)
rounded_cube_yz(size, r=0, xy_center=false, z_center=false)
rounded_rectangle(size, r, center=false, xy_center=true)
rounded_square(size, r, center=true)
// Usage: Pass vector sizes and corner radii as required for the desired shape and rounding.
```

TITLE: Horizontal Holes and Slicing Utilities in OpenSCAD
DESCRIPTION: Includes functions to model staircase-sliced horizontal holes using teardrop-shaped layer features. Functions generate the ordinates for modified teardrop layers and modules create cylinders and holes suitable for layer-based printing with specific overhang constraints.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/readme.md#_snippet_269

LANGUAGE: scad
CODE:
```
`teardrop_minus_x(r, y, h)`
Calculates the adjusted x-coordinate of a teardrop layer segment.

`teardrop_plus_x(r, y, h)`
Calculates the complemented x-coordinate for teardrop modeling.

Modules:
`horicylinder(r, z, h = 0, center = true)`
Creates horizontal cylinders that are dimensionally accurate without supports.
`horihole(r, z, h = 0, center = true)`
Models horizontal holes that do not require support and are precisely dimensioned.

```

TITLE: Defining Global Utilities and Conversion Functions in OpenSCAD
DESCRIPTION: This snippet collects global utility functions and modules for OpenSCAD, including unit conversions, mathematical helpers, and commonly required shape operations. Dependencies include the OpenSCAD standard library, and usage requires inclusion of global_defs.scad for core constants. Parameters cover numeric and list input types for conversions, geometric operations, and list handling. Outputs standardize units (cm, m, mm, inch, foot, yard), support slicing and limiting, and provide consistent color and geometry behaviors. Limitations: Functions handle only compatible input types and are primarily intended for internal library use or extension.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/readme.md#_snippet_282

LANGUAGE: OpenSCAD
CODE:
```
// Global constants, functions, and modules
Len(x)              // Returns length of a list or 0 if not a list
cm(x), m(x), mm(x), inch(x), foot(x), yard(x)   // Unit conversions to mm
echoit(x)           // Echoes and returns x (debugging)
grey(n)             // Returns grey color shade
in(list, x)         // Checks if x is in list
limit(x, min, max)  // Clamps x in range [min, max]
no_point(str)       // Replaces decimal point with 'p' in string
r2sides(r), r2sides4n(r) // Calculates polygon sides from radius
round_to_layer(z)   // Rounds z to layer boundary
slice(list, start=0, end=undef) // Python-style list/string slicing
sqr(x)              // Returns square of x
Modules:
```

TITLE: Defining Fully Fastened Handle Assembly using OpenSCAD
DESCRIPTION: This OpenSCAD module represents the complete handle assembly, including the handle with inserts (by calling `handle_assembly`) and the required screws and washers. It calculates the necessary screw length based on the panel thickness. Unlike `handle_assembly`, it does not use the `assembly()` module itself, causing the screws and washers to be listed in the parent assembly's Bill of Materials and build steps.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/docs/usage.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: OpenSCAD
CODE:
```
module handle_fastened_assembly(thickness) { //! Assembly with fasteners in place
    screw_length = screw_length(screw, thickness, 2, true, longer = true);

    handle_assembly();

    handle_screw_positions()
        vflip()
            translate_z(thickness)
                screw_and_washer(screw, screw_length, true);
}
```

TITLE: Creating Screw Knob in OpenSCAD
DESCRIPTION: This section details a customizable screw knob with an embedded hex head screw. It describes properties like flange radius, thickness, and fluting, along with functions and modules for generating the knob, including solid or wall-only flanges, and wave or fluted edges. Dependencies include OpenSCAD, and it shows how to create a screw knob assembly.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/readme.md#_snippet_249

LANGUAGE: OpenSCAD
CODE:
```
screw_knob_flange_r(type)
// The flange outside radius

// The thickness of the flange
screw_knob_fluted(type)
// Fluted instead of sine wave
screw_knob_screw(type)
// The hex screw
screw_knob_solid(type)
// Is the flange solid or just a wall
screw_knob_stem_h(type)
// The stem height below the flange
screw_knob_wall(type)
// Wall thickness

// Wave amplitude
screw_knob_waves(type)
```

```
screw_knob(screw, wall = 2, stem_h = 6, flange_t = 4, flange_r = 9, solid = true, waves = 5, wave_amp = 2, fluted = false)

```


TITLE: Overriding Sphere Geometry to Ensure Axis Vertices in OpenSCAD
DESCRIPTION: This snippet redefines the standard sphere module to guarantee vertices at the poles and equator, ensuring compatibility with hulling and Minkowski operations in OpenSCAD. Required dependencies are the OpenSCAD standard sphere module, with this override replacing or wrapping it. Parameters include radius (r) and optional diameter (d). The output is a sphere with `$fn` (facet number) as a multiple of four and consistent axis vertices, preserving intended model dimensions after solid unions. Limitation: Overrides built-in sphere; use only when such guarantees are needed.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/readme.md#_snippet_285

LANGUAGE: OpenSCAD
CODE:
```
// Axis-aligned sphere override
sphere(r=1, d=undef) // Custom sphere with vertices at all half axes
// Usage: Replace OpenSCAD's default sphere for models where hull/minkowski dimension precision is required.
```


TITLE: Defining Handle Sub-Assembly with Inserts using OpenSCAD
DESCRIPTION: This OpenSCAD module defines the geometry for a 3D printed handle with heat-fit inserts already installed. It uses the `assembly()` module to mark itself as a step in the build manual, includes a build instruction comment, and sets a specific pose for its representation in the manual. It does not represent the final assembly with all fasteners.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/docs/usage.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: OpenSCAD
CODE:
```
//
//! Place inserts in the bottom of the posts and push them home with a soldering iron with a conical bit heated to 200°C.
//
module handle_assembly() pose([225, 0, 150], [0, 0, 14]) //! Printed part with inserts in place
assembly("handle", ngb = true) {
    translate_z(handle_height())
        stl_colour(pp1_colour) vflip() handle_stl();

    handle_screw_positions()
        vflip()
            insert(insert);
}
```

TITLE: Creating Supportless Horizontal Holes with Teardrop Shapes in OpenSCAD
DESCRIPTION: This snippet delivers modules for generating teardrop-shaped slots and holes optimized for 3D printing without requiring support material. It depends on core OpenSCAD and NopSCADlib utilities, and is inspired by layup requirements for horizontal holes. Parameters include height, radius, width, centering booleans, chamfer amount, and plus/truncate options for fine-tuning the teardrop profile. Outputs include holes (teardrop, semi_teardrop), plus versions compensating for layer staircasing, and horizontal or vertical teardrop slots. Limitations: Suitable for holes above certain minimum sizes; use 'plus' for optimal round appearance in cross-section.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/readme.md#_snippet_286

LANGUAGE: OpenSCAD
CODE:
```
// Teardrop and supportless slot modules
semi_teardrop(h, r, d=undef, center=true, chamfer=0, chamfer_both_ends=true, plus=false)
teardrop(h, r, center=true, truncate=true, chamfer=0, chamfer_both_ends=true, plus=false)
teardrop_plus(h, r, center=true, truncate=true, chamfer=0, chamfer_both_ends=true)
tearslot(h, r, w, center=true, chamfer=0, chamfer_both_ends=true, plus=false)
vertical_tearslot(h, r, l, center=true, chamfer=0, chamfer_both_ends=true, plus=false)
teardrop_chamfer(h, center, chamfer, chamfer_both_ends) // Internal use
// Usage: Select desired teardrop or slot module, adjust truncation, plus, and chamfer options for printability.
```

TITLE: Mathematical Utilities in OpenSCAD
DESCRIPTION: A comprehensive set of functions for vector and matrix operations, including geometric calculations, hyperbolic functions, roots, transformations, and coordinate conversions. Facilitates complex mathematical modeling and geometric analysis.
SOURCE: https://github.com/nophead/nopscadlib/blob/master/readme.md#_snippet_271

LANGUAGE: scad
CODE:
```
`angle_between(v1, v2)`
Returns the angle in radians between two vectors.

`argcosh(x)`
Inverse hyperbolic cosine.

`circle_intersect(c1, r1, c2, r2)`
Calculates an intersection point of two circles in the X-Z plane.

`degrees(radians)` and `radians(degrees)`
Convert between degrees and radians.

`euler(R)`
Converts a rotation matrix to an Euler rotation vector.

`identity(n, x = 1)`
Creates an identity matrix of size n.

`invert(m)`
Inverts a matrix.

`map(v, func)` and `mapi(v, func)`
Apply functions to vector elements, with optional index.

`nearly_zero(x)`
Checks if a value is close to zero.

`path_length(path, i = 0, length = 0)`
Calculates the length along a path.

`quadratic_real_roots(a, b, c)` and `cubic_real_roots(a, b, c, d)`
Find real roots of quadratic and cubic equations.

`cosh(x)`, `sinh(x)`, `tanh(x)`, and `coth(x)`
Hyperbolic functions.

`reduce(v, func, unity)`
Reduces vector to a single value using a function.

`reverse(v)`
Reverses a vector.

`rot2_z(a)`, `rot3_z(a)`, `rotate(a, v)`
Generate rotation matrices.

`scale(v)`, `translate(v)`
Generate scaling and translation matrices.

`transform(v, m)`, `transform_points(path, m)`
Apply transformations to vectors and paths.

`unit(v)`
Normalizes a vector.

`vec2(v)`, `vec3(v)`, `vec4(v)`
Extract components as vectors.

`xor(a, b)`
Logical exclusive OR.

```
